Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1994, 2002, 2003, 2007, 2012. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.

column9: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column9: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution + tax data, 1981-1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986-1987: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1993: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1997: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1998: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2001: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2002-2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006-2008: survey + tax data, 2009: interpolated survey + tax data, 2010-2015: survey + tax data, 2016: extrapolated distribution + tax data, 2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1992, 1994, 1997, 2005, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column9: The inheritance tax data for 2008-2009 was not used here because of inconsistency of figures in the data. The amount of net personal wealth estimated here is much less than the net household wealth in the National Balance Sheets. The difference could be explained as follows. First, the net household wealth in the National Balance Sheets includes the asset of non-profit sector. Second, the estimate of net personal wealth covers only real estate and financial assets, while other kinds of assets are included in the National Balance Sheets. Third, while the real estates in the National Balance Sheets are those in market prices, they are in government appraisal values, lower than market prices. Considering the share of real estate in the net household wealth is 76% (the average in 2000-2013)  and the total amount in government appraisal values is 67% of that in market prices, the net household wealth would be underestimated as much as 25% at least from the difference in government appraisal values and market prices of real estate.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1986, 1993, 1994, 2002, 2010. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2007, 2014, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1980, 1993, 1997, 1999, 2001, 2005, 2010, 2012. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1980, 1993, 1997, 1999, 2001, 2005, 2010, 2012. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 2001, 2006, 2009. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1987, 1993, 1995, 2000, 2004, 2008, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2006, 2012. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wir2018.wid.world/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Inequality Report 2018[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1984, 1990, 1998, 2000, 2006, 2007, 2013. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1996, 2002, 2007, 2008, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1982: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1983: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1989-1992: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1993-2001: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2002-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”; [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/salverda-wiemer-and-atkinson-anthony-b-2007-top-incomes-in-the-netherlands-over-the-twentieth-century-in-atkinson-a-b-and-piketty-t-editors-top-incomes-over-the-twentieth-century-a/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Salverda, Wiemer and Atkinson, Anthony B. (2007). Top Incomes in the Netherlands over the Twentieth Century; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes over the Twentieth Century. A Contrast Between Continental European and English-Speaking Countries, Oxford University Press, chapter 10. Salverda, Wiemer (2013). Extending the top-income shares for the Netherlands from 1999 to 2012: An explanatory note. Mimeo.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: Series constructed by Wouter Leenders, work-in-progress.;

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1982: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1983: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1989-1992: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1993-2001: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2002-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1992, 1994, 2005, 2007, 2011, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1985, 1992, 2003, 2009. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
