The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1994: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1999: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2001-2002: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2003-2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2011: survey + tax data, 2012-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1983-1989: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1990-1991: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1993-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2002: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2003-2004: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005-2015: survey + tax data, 2016: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2017: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1984, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2013, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1984, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2013, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2000, 2010. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1994, 2001, 2005, 2011. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1999, 2006. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1989, 2003, 2011. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2009. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2009. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2009. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 2000, 2009. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 2000, 2007, 2011. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 2000, 2007, 2011. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/democratisation-and-the-emergence-of-class-conflicts-income-inequality-in-thailand-2001-2016-wid-world-working-paper-2018-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Thanasak Jenmana (2018), Democratisation and the Emergence of Class Conflicts: Income Inequality in Thailand, 2001-2016[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2006, 2011, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1985, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1989, 1992, 1996, 1999, 2002, 2005, 2009, 2012, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1989, 1992, 1996, 1999, 2002, 2005, 2009, 2012, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Assuming the same distribution as fiscal income.
column10: WID.world computations using: [URL][URK_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/WID_METHODOLOGY_NOTES_2015_7_US_v2.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Frank, Sommeiller, Price & Saez (2015), “Series for Top Income Shares by US States since 1917”[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1993, 1996, 1998, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2010, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Inequality series are imputed by assuming that income shares are the same as in Tanzania.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1996, 2011. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2017 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017)[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980-2017: aggregation based on country estimates
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by a given percentile group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. individuals
column7: Net personal wealth share held by a given percentile group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
